text: I have to stand in a line like this and
I hope they'll give me some food even
though I don't have the $2 donation this
time
it gets pretty tough it's very
humiliating
this is Monica Almeida of the New York
Times early in 2008 while the Dow Jones
was still near its all-time high the
recession hit the Inland Empire early
and with a vengeance forcing many to
make difficult choices they never
thought possible last April I began
visiting the Gap Food Bank in Rancho
Cucamonga 40 miles east of Los Angeles
and have continued to go back to see how
people have been coping with the
economic downturn I can't afford the
food at the grocery stores and this is
extra food for me hard times everywhere
gotta make ends meet wherever you can
this had always been an affordable place
to live to buy a home and raise children
but gas prices were over $4 a gallon
we're owning a car as a necessity
the unemployment and foreclosure rates
were already among the highest in the
country
gap stands for God always provides Perry
Blackman has run the food bank for over
15 years serving the working poor many
already struggling to live on minimum
wage we have definitely seen an increase
we've been averaging in the last couple
months about 40 to 50 new families a
week which is huge a lot of single moms
with you know two and three kids just
barely making it I've seen an
interesting change in the last couple
months
not being able to even come because they
can't afford your gas you know if every
50 come new each week albeit you know
six hundred families and there's just no
way that I can do that
we'll have to stop the line at 350 400
and turn away and I haven't had to do
that in 15 years I've never had to turn
a person away
by late December 2008 a recession was
finally declared and massive layoffs
took their toll throughout the new year
no more
the food bank opens at 4:00 p.m. every
Thursday but the line outside begins to
form as early as noon volunteers arrive
early to fill the bags they rely on
donations from corporations and grocery
stores much of it is surplus food but
now businesses are tightening their
inventory the limit on bread now is
about one to two loads per family but
last year it was running through four
loaves or five family we go through at
least one of these pallets a week what
I've got here is pallets that were
donated by a cookie factory there's
nothing really wrong with them other
than a few of them are broken we're
seeing more people in the professional
fields they've never had to come to a
food bank we went from making you know
two three hundred thousand dollars a
year to zero in a matter of a month
Tasha Boyd and her husband Anthony had
thrived during the housing boom Anthony
worked in the mortgage industry but
found a full-time job at a bank when
that slowed down then the banking crisis
followed and he was laid off they have
three young sons I absolutely never
pictured myself standing in a food bank
line I thought okay well if I go to the
food bank and we get enough groceries
for the week and that's fifty to a
hundred dollars less that we have to
spend on groceries at the storm we can
use that towards keeping our water on or
keeping our lights on or paying gas in
our car we've lost our homeowners
insurance our life insurance our health
insurance our car insurance every type
of assurance that we had is no longer so
now we live from day to day from moment
to moment and pray that we will have no
emergency
great the gap is a faith-based
organization father I just week after
week Linda Dietrich a volunteer provides
spiritual support to those who ask her
to pray for them Jesus name sometimes
some of their prayer requests are really
heavy they're you know they're too much
for one person to carry but I have to
let it go I have to say Lord you take it
because I cannot do this I cannot
because the stories are heart-wrenching
Sarah it's disheartening it's easy to
get depressed it's easy to feel
overwhelmed you know it's easy you just
want to lay there in bed and not get out
you know I met Kathy walkins and her
husband Robert shortly after they both
lost their jobs at a luxury boat
building company trying to have some
hope you know for the future try to get
to know some other people that are going
through the same thing you know
going through a lot of isolation feeling
like we're the only ones they had
survived hard times overcome drug abuse
and homelessness they said they were
doing well and back on their feet before
the layoffs came seriously we used to
just go to the grocery store and just
not even think twice there was no budget
no limit to our budget you know it was
just a given that there was always food
there
I'm never going there the first time you
know and thinking that which is just
expecting a whole different type of
people there thinking that it would be
all homeless people you know maybe laugh
at us or something like we see someone
we know you know and I spoke to Cathy a
month later she said that her husband
had left and was back on drugs that she
was going to meetings praying and
searching for work we agreed to stay in
touch but when I try to reach her again
her cell phone was no longer in service
I'm absolutely glad that this happened
because it's helping me to be a better
steward over our finances Tasha and her
family continue to struggle but she sees
it as a temporary situation a lot of
things that we used to do used to be
money based we've learned to find things
that aren't money based like just going
to the park like many who stand in line
at the food bank she does what she has
to do to get through these difficult
times and looks ahead
some days you're you're up and you're
like it's gonna be great and then some
days you're like oh
not another day how many more do we have
out of all the things that we lost the
most important thing that we didn't lose
each other we're still a family were
still a happy family and we still have
her
you
